author:

comments.body: ~I do not think so `check mode` is required for facts module.~
What does this mean? Why would you not want facts during a check mode run?

~This flag denotes that module will not perform any changes to remote system if `--check` is provided while running. Fact modules does not change anything on remote systems so it is pointless to have `supports_check_mode` as True. Moreover, there is no action performed with respect to `module.check_mode` like done [here](https://github.com/ansible/ansible/blob/2ad7d79985fef9abc2ee1c5166762b5773cf5c4d/lib/ansible/modules/cloud/vmware/vmware_guest.py#L2095).~

If a module does not support check mode (i.e., `supports_check_mode=False`), then it will be skipped when run in check mode. If we skip a facts module in check mode, then it could significantly impact the run -- facts could be missing that many tasks depend on, for instance. Additionally, since this module *never* changes anything, it doesn't need to do anything special for check mode.

So yes, this module *does* support check mode: it always runs in a manner that doesn't change anything, but only predicts if anything would be changed (spoiler alert: it wouldn't). And moreover, changing this line to `False` could have unnecessary negative effects if someone were to depend on facts from this module that would then become unavailable in check mode _for no good reason_.

To put it differently:

`supports_check_mode=True` does *not* mean "this module does something differently in check mode." It *does* mean "this module can be run in a way that doesn't make changes, only reports them." And that's what this module does *every* time, so clearly it supports check mode.
Make sense to me. Thanks for info.

@@ -1,1 +124,128 @@        mutually_exclusive=(('password', 'token'), ),

comments.body: Could you please use `github3.py` instead of `PyGithub` as this will match with other github_* modules ?
As I mentioned on the other review, `github3.py` has pretty bad GitHub Enterprise support, so no.
I think this will add additional overhead of separate library to both user and maintainer. So -1 from my side.

So what would be an appropriate path forward here? `github3.py` is really bad at talking to GitHub Enterprise, so it's clearly not an option. Are you suggesting that I first port the other GitHub-related models to PyGithub in order to merge this?

Blocking this review on the fact that the *other* Github-related modules made a poor choice of library isn't terribly reasonable IMO. So I'd like to know what you suggest to move forward. (Aside from using `github3.py`, of course, since it doesn't work.)

You are taking me wrong here. I am just saying that adding additional library will add overhead to people who are using this module and people who will maintain it. I am not saying to port other GitHub modules to use `PyGithub`. One way could be using GitHub REST APIs directly rather than relying on any third party Python modules.

I don't see how that's a good choice. It seems to me that the other modules made a poor choice of library, and so going forward we should choose a better one. I've selected PyGithub, but I'm obviously open to other suggestions. What I'm not open to is either a) being required to use the same broken library as the other modules; or b) reinventing the wheel.

@adrianmoisey @Akasurde @andreparames @bincyber @dj-wasabi @djmattyg007 @dsummersl @pcgentry @yeukhon

I believe you've worked on other GitHub modules, it would be good to get your views on this
I would say then port rest of the github modules using `PyGithub` library so that everyone is benefited. What say ?

IMO that sets an unreasonably high barrier to entry, and it's something I have neither the time nor desire to do ATM. I'll leave this PR here in case someone else wants to do it in the future, but it's going to be more appropriate for us to just maintain our own version of this module if that's the cost of getting it merged.

@Akasurde I think you're being unreasonable. There is no technical reason for rejecting this patch. The dependencies for each module are clearly indicated in documentation. I don't see how that could be considered confusing. IMO there are far more pressing quality concerns for Ansible's suite of modules than which API wrapper each github module uses.
OK I am dismissing my all reviews. Thanks.
Making this as resolved.
